item.title: Nintendo tells customers in Japan to expect Switch 2 hardware shortage at launch
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamedeveloper.com/business/nintendo-tells-customers-in-japan-to-expect-switch-2-hardware-shortage

Nintendo president Shuntaro Furukawa has warned that demand for Switch 2 consoles has massively exceeded expectations in Japan and that some consumers will be unable to secure hardware at launch.

In a post on X (via Google Translate), Furukawa explained around 2.2 million people in Japan are attempting to secure a Switch 2 through the My Nintendo Store as part of a lottery process.

He noted the number of applicants has surpassed expectations and "far exceeds the number of Nintendo Switch 2 consoles that can be delivered from the My Nintendo Store [at launch] on June 5th."

"Therefore, unfortunately, we expect that a significant number of customers will not be selected when the winners are announced tomorrow, April 24th," added Furukawa.

Those who are unsuccessful during the first lottery won't have to reapply and will instead be automatically entered into another lottery sale. Nintendo, however, has told customers there will still be some people who are unsuccessful during that second draw.

"Even including the quantity for the second lottery sale, we cannot fulfill all of the applications we received. We deeply apologize for not being able to meet your expectations despite our prior preparations," continued Furukawa.

Nintendo said it is currently strengthening its production chain in response to burgeoning demand. Consumers can also attempt to secure a pre-order through a third-party retailer on April 24, 2025.

Related:Devolver cuts 40 percent of workforce at Reigns developer Nerial

The Switch 2 will continue to be sold on the My Nintendo Store post-launch, with Nintendo pledging to share more details about that process at a later date.

The Japanese company, however, is clearly bracing consumers for disappointment on launch day.

"With the cooperation of retailers, we will continue to ship the console and make efforts to get as many Nintendo Switch 2 consoles as possible into your hands," said Furukawa.

"We plan to continue producing and shipping a considerable number of Nintendo Switch 2 units in the future. We apologize for the delay in our ability to meet your expectations, and we appreciate your understanding."

item.title: Steam users will soon be able to search for games based on accessibility features
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamedeveloper.com/pc/steam-users-will-soon-be-able-to-search-for-games-based-on-accessibility-features

Steam will soon allow players search for games based on accessibility featuresâ€”and developers can start preparing for that new functionality immediately.

Valve explained the Steam store and desktop client will eventually allow users to search for titles with specific accessibility options such as narrated game menus, subtitle options, chat speech-to-text, camera comfort, colour alternatives, and more.

To ensure widespread support, Valve is encouraging developers to outline the accessibility options included in their projects on Steamworks. The company has also rolled out a new accessibility-support questionnaire to help developers effectively describe and self-identify how their games support accessibility.

"If your game has accessibility features, you can now enter that information in the Steamworks 'edit store' section for your app," explained Valve in a blog post. "Later in the year (once we've given developers time to work on it from their end) we'll start sharing the resulting information with players in the Steam store and Steam desktop client."

Valve highly recommends Steam developers support new search feature

The company will roll out a few updates to the Steam store and desktop client "later this year" to expose that information.

Related:EA will shut down Origin later this year

As well as being able to search for titles based on specific accessibility features, Steam users will also be able to view the accessibility features for individual titles on the right hand side of the store page.

Valve noted that developers won't be required to add accessibility information for their Steam releases, but said the practice is "highly recommended."

"We've worked to make it as easy as possible for developers to indicate these features are available by using feedback to standardize these options as much as possible," added the company.
